Award.AbstractNarration:
Data Analytics (DA) is a field that merges quantitative methods in statistics, data mining, and computer science to discover and summarize information in data. In practice, a good application of DA requires comprehensive critical thinking skills that (1) extend beyond the application of quantitative statistical or computational methods and (2) include qualitative forms of thought, such as formalizing potential biases, communicating personal judgment, exploring multiple solutions, assimilating new information with old, and assessing implications of discoveries. Unfortunately, current methods in teaching DA focus primarily on its quantitative aspects; only after students master quantitative theory and methods do they have an opportunity to think critically about applications. Students who fail to complete current DA courses neither develop comprehensive DA skills nor experience how complex quantitative summaries may advance knowledge.

The investigators are attempting to revolutionize current practice in teaching introductory DA to first- and second-year college students. Specifically, they are developing a new course, "Critical Thinking with Data Visualization" (CTDV), which synchronizes teaching methods in DA with critical thinking and makes DA accessible to diverse learners. CTDV includes four modules, each of which is motivated by a different real-world case study and focuses on one DA method (e.g., multidimensional scaling). CTDV uses novel interactive data visualization software (and techniques therein) as a platform for students to build from what they know and construct their understanding of (1) how to think critically, (2) the role of data in problem solving, and (3) some mathematical and computational methods for summarizing complex datasets. The software is based on methods called Bayesian Visual Analytics (BaVA), which have been developed by the investigators (see NSF Award No. 0937071). BaVA enables domain experts--e.g., biologists or homeland security analysts--to assess complex datasets and incorporate their expert knowledge within quantitatively rigorous data characterizations, without technical training in statistics or computer science. For this reason, BaVA fosters creative, critical thinking and problem solving with data and is ideal for experiential learning of DA concepts in the classroom.

The project team is developing CTDV (including its objectives, curriculum, lesson plans, case studies, and course materials), designing the interactive data visualization software (including tests of usability), implementing CTDV (or modules within it), and assessing the success of CTDV. The assessment includes both quantitative (e.g., tests) and qualitative measures (e.g., surveys and interviews) that take place before, during, and after the students experience CTDV. In addition, the team is disseminating CTDV via a comprehensive Web site, papers, and conference workshops.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Data (or Discovery) Analytics (DA) is a field that merges quantitative methods in statistics, machine learning, and computer science to discover and summarize information in data. In practice, learning from data via DA requires comprehensive critical thinking skills which 1) extend beyond the application of quantitative statistical or computational methods and 2) include qualitative forms of thought, such as formalizing potential biases, communicating personal judgement, exploring multiple solutions, assimilating new information with old, and assessing implications of discoveries.   Supported by NSF (Grant # 1141096), practices in DA were synchronized with activities in the classroom.  Novel, transformative, student-centric approaches for teaching all aspects of DA were developed and assessed for students of many levels, including primary, secondary, and university students.

Intellectual Merit and Outcomes:  The new approaches for teaching DA relied on three fundamental, intellectual developments:  1) defining critical thinking in a practical form, 2) creating interactive analytic software for multiple platforms, and 3) combining virtual and physical realities to invent Be the Data.

1) Inspired by The Eight Elements of Thought (Elder and Paul, 2010), critical thinking with data was defined in three parts:  Qualitative-Quantitative-Qualitative (QQQ).  First, analysts think qualitatively about their perspective, scientific goals, current solutions, and research question.  Second, analysts collect data and use quantitative methods to summarize, visualize, and discover features in data.  Third, analysts use qualitative thinking to reflect on analyses, sources of bias, and potential implications of findings.  With the QQQ, DA lessons were developed that focus on one or more Q(s).

2) Paired with QQQ-designed lessons, Andromeda was developed: an interactive software that enables analysts to explore high-dimensional data visually.  A screen shot of Andromeda is provided.  Andromeda projects data using Weighted Multidimensional Scaling (WMDS) (Kruskal and Wish, 1978) and enables students to adjust the projection by dragging data points or sliding variable weights.   Students make the adjustments based on personal hypotheses or curiosities about the data, and students may explore data over the course of many adjustments.  The main advantage of Andromeda is that students may learn from complex datasets without necessarily mastering the high-level mathematical details of WMDS; i.e., students may practice and/or focus on the qualitative Qs in QQQ, as well as experience the quantitative Q when exploring data.  Findings from assessments of Andromeda support that it can enable students to make deeper or more complex insights from data than without it, as well as reinforce technical concepts on which WMDS relies, e.g., distance measures and data dimensionality.

3) Combining NSF support with internal university funding, Andromeda was extended to Be the Data.  Pictures of Be the Data are provided.  Be the Data merges Andromeda with motion detection software so that a class of students may virtually become high-dimensional data points that are represented physically in a room (pictures of Be the Data are provided).  As data points, students explore a dataset by walking around.  For example, provided data about animals with 30 variables that describe animal characteristics (e.g., measures of furriness, fierceness, strength), students embody an animal in Be the Data and orient themselves in different ways to learn from the data.   From a birds-eye view, orientations are projections of high-dimensional data; i.e., two-dimensional maps of high-dimensional data points.  As students move in the room, Be the Data (using machinery from Andromeda) informs the students which variables are most active.  With Be the Data, students work together to generate hypotheses (e.g., about which variables may group certain observations) and/or answer research questions.  For example, in the context of the animal dataset, students may collectively answer questions, such as, “What may make animals good pets?” or “What may make animals good to eat?”  Qualitative and quantitative assessments of Be the Data suggest that students have a positive change in attitude about DA and deepen their understanding for how to learn from high-dimensional data. 

Broader Impacts: Over the life of the grant, innovative DA lessons, Andromeda, and Be the Data were brought to over 500 hundred students, including second graders, teenage girls, and college students.  Education and analytic advancements made from this grant, were presented to research and instructional faculty at conferences and shared in ten academic journals or conference proceedings.  Three graduate students worked directly on this grant (developing and assessing Andromeda and Be the Data), while other graduate students supported the effort as part of a larger academic team.  For the three students, research from this grant was the primary focus of their master’s theses or doctoral dissertations.  To conclude, the impact of this grant will continue indefinitely, as two university courses were developed.
